chapter.title: Outputting Cards
chapter.para: Cards can be output in a number of different ways, including printing on a printer, and saving images of the cards as JPEG files. Each of these methods is described in the sections below, but first, how do you determine the number of cards that will be printed?

section.title: Determining the Number of Cards That Will Be Printed
section.para: The number of cards that will be printed is determined by the total number of QSOs selected, and the maximum number of QSOs that can printed on a card. Other factors are the order that the QSOs are sorted, and any macros containing ADIF fields that are used on the card.

To determine the number of cards that will be printed, select the Cards -> Calculate Number of Cards to be Printed... menu item. This opens the dialog shown in the image below. The number of cards shown in the dialog corresponds to the QSOs that were loaded, selected and sorted in the Get Started tutorial, and the card that was designed in that tutorial.
To determine the number of sheets of cardstock that are needed, divide the number of cards by the number of cards that will be printed per page, and round up.

figure.title: Number of Cards to be Printed Dialog

section.title: Defining Custom Paper Sizes
section.para: There are 118 standard paper sizes defined in the Windows operating system. These sizes are defined for paper and envelopes. Some paper sizes cannot be supported on some printer models because these paper sizes are larger than the largest paper size that the printer can handle. For example, A3 paper is 297 by 420 mm (approximately 11.7 by 16.5 inches). This paper cannot be inserted into a printer whose width is limited to US letter (8 1/2 inches or 216 mm wide) or A4 (210 mm or 8.3 inches wide) paper. In some other cases, the printer manufacturer may decide not to support a printer size because it is a size that is rarely used.

Most printers support defining custom paper sizes, either on a system wide basis, or for a single print job. In the former case, the paper size is defined once for the printer and it becomes available to all programs that allow the user to select the paper size. In the latter case, the custom paper size is available only for one print job; if the paper size is needed again, it must be defined in the next print job.

The following two subsections show how to define a system wide custom paper size for printers that support it, and a tool for defining a custom paper size in HamQSLer that is saved so that it may be reused in future card print jobs. In both subsections, a custom paper size for bureau cards will be created.

section.title: Defining a System Wide Custom Paper Size
section.para: As mentioned above, this method only works if your printer supports it.
Open the Devices and Printers dialog, available from the Start menu and from the Control Panel. The dialog is called Printers and Faxes in Windows XP. This dialog looks similar to the image below.

This image shows the Devices and Printers dialog on my computer which runs Windows 7. The printers and faxes are listed in the second section of the dialog. To define a custom paper size, move the mouse cursor over the printer you want to define the paper size for, and click the right mouse button to bring up the context menu. Select the Printing preferences menu item. This will display the printing preferences dialog, which probably contains a number of tabs with labels such as Printing Shortcuts, Features, and Advanced. Select the Features tab. You should then see a panel similar to the image below, which is what is displayed on Windows 7 for HP printers.

figure.title: Features Panel on Printing Preferences Dialog

section.para: The size dropdown box, highlighted above, shows the default paper size for the printer. Click on the dropdown box to open it. The contents will look similar to the image below.

figure.title: Features Panel on Printing Preferences Dialog

section.para: The dropdown contains one or more standard paper sizes, and may contain custom paper sizes that you defined in the past. If you select the More... item, a dialog is opened that allows you to change the default paper size for your printer. Any custom paper sizes that you define are probably listed at the bottom. Since we are not interested in changing the default paper size, you can ignore this menu item.

The last menu item is Custom... If this item is present, you can define custom paper sizes; if it is not present, then you must set your custom paper sizes using the method in the section below. Click on the Custom... item to open the custom paper size dialog, shown in the following image. If your printer is not manufactured by HP, or you are not running Windows 7, then the dialog will not look exactly like this.

To define a custom paper size for bureau cards, enter a Width of 3.5 inches or 88.9 mm, and enter a Length of 5.5 inches or 139.7 mm. Change the name to Bureau Card or whatever else you want to call your card. When you change the paper size name, the Save button becomes active. Click this button to save the new custom paper size, then click the OK button to close the dialog. Your new custom paper size will be available from the standard print dialog that is displayed when you print from most programs. This paper size will also be available from the print dialog in HamQSLer. Printing cards in HamQSLer is discussed below.

tip.para: Always set the width in the custom paper size dialog to the smaller dimension of your custom paper size, and the length to the larger dimension. HamQSLer assumes that the paper sizes are set for Portrait mode.

caution.para: Your printer may limit the number of custom paper sizes that you can define. If you need to define additional paper sizes for use with HamQSLer, use the method described in the following section.

section.title: Defining a Custom Paper Size for HamQSLer Only
section.para: If your printer does not support setting system wide custom paper sizes, you may use the method described here to create a custom size that can be used only within HamQSLer.
To define a custom paper size, select the Tools -> Define Custom Paper Sizes menu item. This opens the custom paper sizes dialog shown in the image below.

The Name dropdown box contains the names of all custom paper sizes you have already defined in HamQSLer and the word Custom. To make changes to any of the paper sizes you have defined, select that paper size name. Otherwise, select Custom. Note that Custom is the default value when you open this dialog.

The text box below the dropdown contains the name of the custom paper size you are working with. When you select a paper size from the dropdown, the text in this text box is automatically set to the name you selected.

To define a new bureau card paper size, select Custom. The paper size that is displayed is the default paper size on the default printer on your computer system. Enter a width of 3.5 inches or 88.9 mm and a height of 5.5 inches or 139.7 mm. Change the name from Custom to Bureau Card or similar. When you change the name from Custom to another value, the Save button is enabled. Click this button to save the new paper size, then click the Close button to close the dialog.
This new paper size will be displayed at the end of the paper sizes in the paper size dropdown in the print dialog for HamQSLer.

tip.para: Always enter the smaller paper dimension in the width field and the larger dimension in the height field. HamQSLer assumes the paper sizes are defined in Portrait mode.

caution.para: Only use this method to define custom paper sizes if you cannot define a system wide custom paper size for your printer. Defining a custom paper size using the instructions in this section means that the paper size is available in HamQSLer only.

The custom paper sizes created using this method are stored in the user preferences file. If you delete, move, or lose this file, the custom paper sizes are lost along with all other user preferences settings. You will then have to redefine your custom paper sizes.

section.title: Print Modes and Printer Margins
section.para: Most printers support two modes of printing: borderless and bordered printing. Borderless printing is normally used for printing photographs. The printer increases the image size by a few percent to ensure that the image is larger than the paper size so that the image being printed completely covers the paper. A small portion of the edges of the image are outside the boundaries of the paper. This is usually not noticed when you print a photograph, but will be noticeable if you print multiple QSL cards in borderless mode, especially if you select a cards layout on the page where the one or more cards is positioned at the edges of the page. Here is an example of four bureau sized cards printed along the top edge of a sheet of letter sized paper in borderless mode.

Compare the left sides of the cards on the left with the left sides of the cards on the right. Notice that the left edge of the cards on the left have been clipped. Similarly, the right side of the cards on the right have been clipped. Now compare the top edge of the cards at the top with the cards on the row below. Again, the top of the cards at the top have been clipped. You should only select a borderless paper size if you are centering the cards on the page, or are printing on a paper size that is the same size as the cards being printed.

Now, let's look at bordered printing. In this mode, every printer has a minimum margin along each edge of the paper. These minimum margins vary from printer model to printer model and may not be the same size on each side. For example, the HP Officejet 6500 printer has margins of 0.125 inch (3.175 mm) on every side; the HP Photosmart 7960 series printers have minimum margins of 0.125, 0.07, 0.135, and 0.583 inch or 3.175, 1.778, 3.429, and 14.817 mm. How do you determine the minimum margins for you printers? HamQSLer includes a tool for that. See Determining Printer Minimum Margins below.

Obviously mimimum margins would lead to a problem if you attempted to print cards using a cards layout that positioned the cards on one or more edges of the page. The edges of the cards that are positioned at the edges of the page are clipped, producing a white margin on those edges. Provided the minimum margins are less than 0.25 inch or 6.35 mm, HamQSLer has a setting that allows you to clip the printing around the edges of each card to match the largest minimum margin for the printer. See Printer Properties and Print Properties, below for more information.

section.title: Determining Printer Minimum Margins
section.para: As discussed above, printer minimum margins determine where on a page you can actually print. HamQSLer provides a tool to enumerate these margins. To open the tool, select the Tools -> Show Printer Margins.

The printer minimum margins dialog opens. The printer dropdown box lists all of the printers installed on the user's computer, with the default printer selected, and the margins listed below the dropdown. The image below shows the result on my computer.
The margins are displayed in a dark green color, and as you can see, all margins are the same size.

figure.title: Printer Minimum Margins Dialog - Uneven Margins

section.para: The image above shows the printer minimum margins with the HP Photosmart 7960 series printer selected. The margins are all different sizes, and the bottom margin is greater than 0.25 inch or 6.35 mm. The value for this margin is displayed in red, and a warning message is shown below the margins. The meaning of the message is discussed in the next section.
The minimum printer margins are a physical property of each printer, are set by the printer manufacturer, and are not user changeable.

section.title: Printer Properties and Print Properties
section.para: Printer settings and print settings may be set in three locations:

listitem.para: The settings in user preferences are program default settings. These settings are transferred to the card file when a new card is created.
Each card has a set of card specific default settings. The card specific default printer and print settings should be set to values that the user would normally use when printing that card.
Finally, when the user selects the Print Cards... menu item, the card specific print and printer settings are copied to the print dialog, where the user can modify them for that specific print job.

section.para: The image below shows the printer properties and print properties in the card properties panel. The same properties are displayed in the user preferences dialog; these properties are also displayed in the print dialog when printing cards.

section.title: Printer Properties
section.para: The printer dropdown box contains a list of all of the printers that are installed on the computer. The paper size dropdown box lists all of the paper sizes for the selected printer, and the quality dropdown box lists all of the print resolution values for the selected printer. Finally, the paper source dropdown lists all of the papersources or trays for the selected printer. If there is only one paper source, this dropdown box is disabled.

When the user selects a different printer, the paper size, quality, and paper source dropdowns are reloaded with the lists that are valid for the newly selected printer. An attempt is then made to set the selected values to the previously selected values. For example, if the paper size for the first printer was selected to be A4, then when a new printer is selected, an attempt is make to select A4 as the paper size. Similarly, an attempt is made to select the previous quality and paper source values. If these values cannot be found in the list, then the default paper size, quality, and paper source values for the newly selected printer are selected.

caution.para: Even though the same paper sizes may exist on multiple printers, the name given to these paper sizes may be different. As a result, the printer's default paper size would be selected. For example, the name for the A4 paper size on the HP OfficeJet 6500 is A4 210x297mm and the name on the HP Photosmart 7960 series of printers is A4. So, even though the paper size is A4 in both cases, the names are different, and when the user switches between these printers, the default paper size would be selected in the paper size dropdown box.
Similarly, the quality and paper source selected values may be set to the newly selected printer's default values.

tip.para: The default printer and its default properties may be set in the Devices and Printers section of the Control Panel.

section.para: The default printer, paper size, quality, and paper source in the user preferences are set to the default computer values when the user preference file is created. Any changes made by the user in the user preferences dialog are saved to the user preferences file.

caution.para: If the printer that is set in user preferences is uninstalled, the printer and printer properties will be reset to those for the new default printer on the computer.

section.para: When a card is created, the printer and printer properties that are stored in user preferences are used to initialize the same values for the card.

caution.para: If the printer that is set for the card is uninstalled, then the printer and printer properties for the card will be reset to those for the new default printer on the computer.

section.para: Finally, when the print dialog is opened during printing, the printer and printer properties in the print dialog are set to the values set for the card.

Set the user preferences printer properties to the values that you would normally use for printing QSL cards. There may be instances where, for a specific QSL card, you would want to normally print them on a different printer or with different printer properties. For example, you may have a number of bureau sized QSL cards designed that you would print on one printer using either letter or A4 sized cardstock, but also have a 4 inch by 6 inch card that you would want to print on a photo printer using 4 inch by 6 inch photo paper instead. For this, you would set the user preferences to the printer and properties that you will be using for most cards, and set the card specific printer and properties of the larger card to those for your photo printer.

Finally, when you print the cards, you can change the printer and printer settings again for that specific printer job. One place you may want to do this is if you are not at your normal workplace or home and want to print some cards using someone else's printer.

section.title: Print Properties
section.para: There are four print properties, two of which are related to printer margins, and two which are not. We will first look at the two that are not affected by print margins.

The Print Card Outlines checkbox determines whether a black line is printed around the edge of the cards. This outline is useful for cutting the cards from the cardstock after printing. If the checkbox is checked, the outline is printed; if the checkbox is not checked, the outline is not printed.
If this checkbox is checked in the card properties panel, the outline is also displayed on the card in design mode.

When printing a number of cards on cardstock, the total number of cards being printed may not be evenly divisible by the number of cards per page. If they are not, then the last page being printed would contain less than a full page of cards. This is wasteful of cardstock. The user may print additional cards with no QSOs printed in the QSOs Box on the last page and fill in the QSO data by hand at a later time. Filling the last page is accomplished using the Fill Last Page With Blank Cards checkbox. With the checkbox checked, the blank cards will be printed; with the checkbox unchecked, no blank cards are printed.

Printer margins were discussed in the Print Modes and Printer Margins section, above. As mentioned, the printer margins determine how close to the edge of a page the printer will print. The first print property that is affected by the printer margins is the Set Card Margins to Printer Margins checkbox. Checking this checkbox leaves a margin around the inside of each card equal to the size of the widest margin for the selected printer. With the checkbox unchecked, the contents of the card are printed to all edges of the card. This checkbox also has an effect in card design mode; if the checkbox is checked, the margin is displayed on the card. The image below shows the card created in the Getting Started chapter with the Set Card Margins to Printer Margins checkbox checked. The Print Card Outlines checkbox was also checked to better show the card edges. As you can see, there is a clean margin around the inside edges of the card. This margin allows the user to print cards out to the edges of the cardstock without only one or two edges having margins and without uneven margins.

If you want to print cards without a margin, you cannot print to the edges of the page. The Print Inside Printer Margins checkbox determines whether the cards can be printed to the edges of the cardstock or must be printed inside the printer margins. Checking the checkbox forces the cards to be printed inside the printer margins; unchecking the checkbox allows cards to be printed up to the edges of the cardstock. As you will learn in the Print Cards section which follows, unchecking this checkbox does not force cards to be printed on the edges of the cardstock. There are a number of ways to layout the cards on the cardstock; this setting simply allows the user to select a cards layout that prints cards out to the edges of the cardstock.
What happens if the maximum printer margin is large. Have a look at the following image.

In this image, the margins are 14.8 mm or 0.58 inch. As you can see, this does not look good at all and there is little space for actual card content. For this reason, if the largest printer margin is greater than 0.25 inch or 6.35 mm, the Print Inside Printer Margins checkbox is checked, the Set Card Margins to Printer Margins checkbox is unchecked, and both checkboxes are disabled so that the user cannot change their settings. This forces cards to be printed with no margins and inside the printer margins for the cardstock.

section.title: Printing Cards
section.para: HamQSLer prints cards with QSO information in the QSOs Box on each card. If no QSOs are loaded or selected for printing, then a single page of cards with no QSO information in the QSOs Box is printed.

caution.para: The cards are printed with QSOs in the order that they are sorted in the QSOs tab. Be sure to sort the cards in the order you want them printed.

section.para: To print cards, the card must be loaded into the program, and the card's tab must be selected. That is, the card must be displayed in the program's main window.
Select the Cards -> Print Cards... menu item. This will open the print cards dialog which is shown in the image below.

The printer properties and print properties group boxes are the same as in the user preferences dialog and the card properties panel. The values in the controls in these group boxes are loaded with same values as the controls in the card properties panel. This is the user's last chance to make changes to these properties before the cards are printed. Any changes made only affect this print job; the card properties are not modified by changes made in the print cards dialog.

There is one additional group box in the dialog: the cards layout group box. The radio buttons displayed in this box show how the cards will be laid out on the cardstock when they are printed. For each layout, the cards are displayed in white with a blue line around them. The area in light pink shows the cardstock on which the cards will be printed. In each row of layouts, the cards are laid out as follows: top left card is positioned at the top left corner of the cardstock, top left card is centered left to right and positioned at the top of the cardstock, and finally, the cards are printed to be centered on the cardstock. In the image above, the first row shows the layouts for cards printed on cardstock in portrait orientation, and the second row shows the layouts in landscape orientation.

If cards cannot be printed on the cardstock in one of the orientations, then that row of layouts is not displayed in the dialog. For example, the image below shows the cards layout group box for bureau sized cards on 4 by 6 inch paper. Because the card width is greater than the 4 inches, cards cannot be printed on the paper in portrait orientation, so the portrait layouts are not shown.
If the paper size selected is smaller than the size of the cards to be printed, then only a warning message is shown. See the image below for an example.

figure.title: Print Cards Dialog With Paper Size Too Small

section.para: The message "The selected paper size is smaller than the card size. No cards can be printed." is displayed in red in the cards layout group box and the Print and Preview buttons are disabled.

As mentioned previously, checking the Print Inside printer Margins checkbox affects the layout of cards on the cardstock. The cards are printed so that the edges of the cards are at or inside the printer margins. The image below shows the layouts for bureau sized cards on letter sized cardstock. It is not easy to see, but in portrait mode, the cards in the first two layouts have been moved to the left and down.

There is a much greater effect on the layouts in landscape mode. Bureau cards are 5.5 inches wide and letter sized paper is 11 inches wide in landscape mode. So, two cards can just be printed across the paper in landscape mode. However, if the cards are to be printed inside the printer margins, then only one card wide can be printed. Compare this image to the image in Figure 9.7. The only difference in settings is that the Print Inside Printer Margins is checked for Figure 9.10.

tip.para: There are three manufacturers of cardstock that is micro-perforated for printing of bureau sized cards. In all cases, the cardstock is letter sized (8 1/2 by 11 inches). The QSLKit provides cardstock for printing four cards per page using the top left or top center landscape layout. QslPaper.com provides cardstock for printing four cards per page using the center landscape layout. Yourofficestop.com provides 3UPPCSTOCK cardstock for printing 3 cards per page using the center portrait layout.
Avery provides a number of letter sized, micro-perforated cardstocks for printing four 4.25 by 5.5 inch cards per page.

section.para: The print cards dialog contains three buttons: Print, Preview, and Cancel. These buttons perform the expected functions.

Selecting the Print button prints the cards. A message box, like the one in the image below is displayed and updated for each page of cards as they are printed. When the last past page is printed, the message box disappears.

Printing is an asynchronous operation. As a print job is performed, the output is queued to the printer queue, and control returns to the program. Only then will the printer start printing the cards. This has a number of advantages:

listitem.para: The program does not have to wait for the printer to finish printing before it regains control.
Print jobs may be queued to the printer so that the user does not have to wait for a print job from another program to finish before he can print cards.
Print jobs may be queued to printers that are offline (disconnected, powered down, etc.) and the print jobs will remain in the queue until the printer is brought online.

section.para: Selecting the Preview button displays the print preview dialog and the message box shown in the image above is displayed until the last page of cards is processed. The first page of cards is displayed in the print preview dialog. For example, the image below shows the print preview dialog as displayed if you followed the Getting Started tutorial.

The first thing to notice is that the cards as displayed on the page in the dialog are shifted up and to the left by an amount equal to the minimum left and top printer margins. This is an artefact of the print preview processing. If these cards are printed, they will be positioned properly on the cardstock and not as shown in the print preview.
There are a number of buttons and other controls on the toolbar at the top of the dialog. The following table describes what each button and control does.

table.title: Print Preview Toolbar Controls and What They Do

row.entry: Print the cards. This is equivalent to clicking the Print button in the print dialog.

section.title: Saving Card as a JPEG
section.para: A card, with or without QSO data, may be saved as a JPEG file for display on a website or for sending over the Internet. To do this, select the Cards -> Save Card as Jpeg... menu item. This opens the JPEG Image Properties dialog which is shown below.

The various controls in this dialog set properties of the image. If you want to include QSO data in the image, then check the Show QSOs checkbox. The card in the image will contain the QSOs that would appear on the first card if you were printing cards.

The resolution dropdown box contains three commonly used values; 96 DPI is the value to use for displaying cards on a computer, such as from a website. This corresponds approximately to the typical resolution of a computer monitor, so the cards will appear about lifesize on the monitor. 300 and 600 DPI are good values for printing or for sending to a QSL card printer. The dropdown box value is also editable so you can enter any value you want.

JPEG files use a lossy compression when they are saved, so when a file is saved, its quality will decrease somewhat. The quality dropdown box contains a number of values that control the amount of compression that is applied when the card is saved. Quality values vary between 0 and 100, with 100 being the best quality. Even at 100, there is some compression applied.

There is a link between quality and the size of the image file; the higher the quality setting, the larger the file size. For example, take the sample card that was created in the Getting Started tutorial. The table below shows the size of the file that is created at each of four quality values, with the resolution set to 300 DPI.
When the user clicks the OK button, a Save As dialog opens so that a file name for the image file may be entered, and a directory may be selected to save the file in.

tip.para: There is no discernable difference in quality of the image between 95 and 100, yet the file size for an image saved at 100 is more than twice the size of the same image saved at 95. The best compromise between image quality and file size is 85. The card images that are displayed on the website are saved at 85. Some images have been saved two or three times at this quality setting.

caution.para: If an image is saved as a JPEG, and then loaded into an image editing program and resaved multiple times, the quality of the image will gradually decrease. However, even with a quality of 85, an image may be resaved a few times before there is any discernable loss of quality when the image is displayed.

tip.para: If you want to have your QSL card added to the sample cards on the website, please use the following settings: Show QSOs checked, resolution of 96 DPI, quality of 85. Because of the use of macros in the card, QSOs should be printed on the card. You can use the QSOs that are included in the sample.adi file in the Samples directory. I promise not to claim credit for any QSOs that are included on the card.

section.title: Saving 4-Up Bureau Cards For Printing
section.para: HamQSLer allows the user to save a set of four blank bureau-sized cards as a JPEG file for sending to a print shop or a QSL card printer for printing large quantities of the the cards. To save the blank cards, select the Cards -> Save 4-Up Cards For Printing... menu item. This action opens the dialog shown in the image below.

figure.title: JPEG Image Properties for 4 Up Blank Bureau Cards Dialog

section.para: There are only two options available: the Include Card Outlines checkbox controls whether a black line is included around the outside of the card or not, and the resolution dropdown box controls the resolution that the image is saved at. There are only two values provided in this dropdown box: 300 DPI and 600 DPI. These are standard values that are used when printing. The dropdown box is also editable, so you can enter any value that you wish.

When the OK button is clicked a Save As dialog box opens to allow the user to enter a name for the file, and to select a directory to save the file in. When the image has been saved, the message "Card image has been saved to (filename) is displayed in the status bar of the main window.
The cards are saved in a two by two array. The image is 7 by 11 inches in size, so the image may be printed lifesize on either letter or A4 sized cardstock.

caution.para: Only bureau sized cards may be saved as a set of 4-up cards.

section.title: Saving Cards For Printing
section.para: Instead of printing cards with QSO data on them, the cards may be saved in a set of JPEG files for sending or taking to a photo print shop. To create these image files, the user must select the Cards -> Save Cards For Printing... menu item. When this is done, the browse for folder dialog box, shown below, is displayed.

The user must select a directory to save the image files in. Once the directory has been selected and the OK button is clicked, the card images are generated and saved in the selected directory. The files are saved with filenames qslXXX.jpg, where XXX is a number that is incremented for each card.

Filenames start at qsl1.jpg. If the selected directory already contains files named qslXXX.jpg, then the number in the filename of the first file saved is set to one more than the highest value of XXX. That is, if there is a file called qsl25.jpg in the directory, the first file saved will be qsl26.jpg.

As the files are being created, the text "Creating card X of Y cards" where X is the number of the card being created and Y is the total number of cards being created is displayed in the status bar of the main window. When all of the files have been created, the text "Y of Y cards created in directory: (directory)" is displayed in the status bar.

tip.para: Create a subdirectory in the hamqsler directory to contain the card images. Name the file Printing or something similar so that you know what the directory contains.

caution.para: The card images are placed in an image that is 4 by 6 inches (10 by 15 cm) in size. Because of this, only bureau cards and 4 by 6 inch cards may be saved for printing.
